document.docTitle: Pelagobia rubromaculata Kolbasova & Neretina 2021, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: A new species of Pelagobia (Lopadorrhynchidae, Annelida), with some notes on literature records of Pelagobia longicirrata Greeff, 1879

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A new species of Pelagobia (Lopadorrhynchidae, Annelida), with some notes on literature records of Pelagobia longicirrata Greeff, 1879

Arrow shows spines on chaetal shafts.

subSubSection.paragraph: Diagnosis. Prostomium triangle, eyes with lenses. Pair of pharyngeal jaws. Tentacular cirri without aciculae. Shafts with fine spines, blades serrated. Pygidium with two rudimental appendages.

Material examined.
Holotype ZMMU MSU WS14781 , paratypes ZMMU MSU WS14782 and ZMMU MSU WS14783 (
8.04.2019
,
0–10 m
, 12°4′32″ N , 109°18′48″ E , Noi Island ) preserved in 96% ethanol
.
Paratypes ZMMU MSU WS14775
–
ZMMU MSU WS14777 (
8.04.2019
,
0–10 m
, 12°4′32″ N , 109°18′48″ E , Noi Island ), mounted on an aluminum stub and sputter-coated with an Au-Pd mixture after SEM
.

Other material :
paratypes ZMMU MSU WS14784–14785 (
8.04.2019
,
0–10 m
, 12°4′32″ N , 109°18′48″ E , Noi Island ) in 96% ethanol
.

Material used for DNA extraction:
ZMMU MSU XZ4956–4958 (
8.04.2019
,
0–10 m
, 12°15′53″ N , 109°20′36″ E , Dung Island )
,
ZMMU MSU XZ4959 and XZ4960 (
8.04.2019
,
0–10 m
, 12°4′32″ N , 109°18′48″ E , Noi Island )
.

paragraph.materialsCitation: Holotype : ZMMU MSU WS14781 ( Fig. 2A ). Adult complete specimen with 14 segments. Body c-curved, pharynx extruded. Prostomium 120 µm long, 200 µm wide, with pair of bright red spots on end. Tentacular cirri of 200 µm long. Body length 2 mm , maximum width excluding parapodia 330 µm. Parapodia 120–330 µm long, chaetae 240–320 µm long. Pygidium with pair of short cirri. Body white, non-transparent, with 10 pairs of brown spots on base of 1– 10 pairs of parapodia.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Paratype ZMMU MSU WS14782 ( Fig. 2B ). Adult female, full of eggs. Body s-curved, with 14 segments. Pygidium lost, pharynx extruded. Prostomium 120 µm long, 200 µm wide, with pair of bright red spots on end. Tentacular cirri of 180 µm long. Body length 2 mm , maximum width without parapodia 415 µm. Parapodia 100–250 µm long, chaetae 240–300 µm long. Body white, non-transparent, with 11 pairs of brown spots on base of 1–11 pairs of parapodia
.

Paratype ZMMU MSU WS14783 ( Fig. 2C ). Adult complete specimen with 14 segments. Pharynx extruded. Prostomium 120 µm long, 200 µm wide Tentacular cirri of 200 µm long. Body length 1.8 mm , maximum width without parapodia 360 µm. Parapodia 110–250 µm long, chaetae 100–240 µm long. Pygidium with pair of short cirri. Body white, non-transparent, with 11 pairs of brown spots on base of 1– 11 pairs of parapodia
.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 2.
Pelagobia rubromaculata
sp. nov.
, type specimens. (A) holotype ZMMU MSU WS14781, entire specimen, dorsal view, (B) paratype WS ZMMU MSU WS14782, entire specimen, dorsal view, (C) paratype ZMMU MSU WS14781, entire specimen, dorsal view.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Paratype ZMMU MSU WS14775 . Adult complete specimen with 12 segments. Prostomium 130 µm long, 200 µm wide. Pair of short filiform antennae and pair of short filiform palps. Two pairs of tentacular cirri of 180 µm long on tentacular segment. Body length 1.6 mm , maximum width excluding parapodia 230 µm. Parapodia 100–180 µm long, chaetae 200–210 µm long. Pygidium with pair of short cirri
.

Paratype ZMMU MSU WS14776 . Adult complete specimen with 14 segments. Prostomium 110 µm long, 170 µm wide. Pharynx everted. Pair of short filiform antennae and pair of short filiform palps. Two pairs of tentacular cirri of 180 µm long on tentacular segment. Body length 1.6 mm , maximum width excluding parapodia 230 µm. Parapodia 100–180 µm long, chaetae 200–210 µm long. Pygidium with pair of short cirri. Each pygidial cirrus ends with tiny terminal papilla
.

Paratype ZMMU MSU WS14777 . Adult specimen with 16 segments. Prostomium 150 µm long, 200 µm wide. Pharynx everted
.

Pair of short filiform antennae and pair of short filiform palps. Two pairs of tentacular cirri of 200 µm long on tentacular segment. Dorsal cirrus on third right parapodium lost. Body length 2.3 mm , maximum width excluding parapodia 400 µm. Parapodia 120–250 µm long, chaetae 200–260 µm long. Pygidium with pair of short cirri.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 3.
Pelagobia rubromaculata
sp. nov.
(based on all type material). (A) anterior end, ventral view, chaetae are not shown, (B) jaws, (C) parapodium of the third segment, (D) heterogomph compound chaetae with serrated shaft. E, general view, chaetae are not shown. Abbreviations: ac—acicula, an—antennae, dc—dorsal cirrus, ey—eyes, no—nuchal organ, p—palps, tc—tentacular cirri, vc—ventral cirri.

subSubSection.paragraph: Description. Body flattened, fusiform, 1.5–2.3 mm long, with 11–15 segments ( Figs 2A, B, C ). Both live and preserved worms semi-transparent, white, with two or four rows of brownish-red spots along dorsal side on parapodial bases ( Figs 2A, B, C , 3E ). Prostomium triangle, with two pairs of thin filiform appendages (pair of antennae and pair of palps), of about 0.75 length of prostomium ( Figs 3A , 4A, B ). Some specimens with bright red spots on bases of antennae ( Fig. 2B ). Red eyes with lenses on dorsal side of prostomium ( Fig. 3A ). Nuchal organs indistinct, accrete to latero-posterior sides of prostomium ( Figs 2A, B, C , 3A ). Pharynx with pair of small jaws; each jaw consists of basal part and falcate proximal one ( Figs 3A, B ). Tentacular segment with minute parapodia with aciculae and fascicles of 3–4 compound chaetae ( Figs 3A , 5A ). Two pairs of short tentacular cirri of subequal length, reaching posterior edge of third body segment ( Figs 3A , 4A, B , 5A ). Acicular structures in tentacular cirri absent. Parapodia of second segment without dorsal cirri ( Figs 3A , 4A , 5A ). From third segment all parapodia with digitiform, taper- ing dorsal and ventral cirri; dorsal cirri reach nearly end of chaetae; ventral cirri slightly shorter ( Figs 3A, C , 4A , 5A ). Each parapodium with tuft of 16—24 chaetae and one thick median projecting acicula ( Fig. 3C ). All chaetae compound spinigers ( Fig. 3D , 6A ). Shafts long, heterogomph, with numerous fine denticles (using light microscopy difficult to see even under oil immersion) ( Figs 3D , 6A, C ). Blades serrated ( Figs 3D , 6A, C ). Pygidium with two short conical cirri terminating with papillae ( Fig 3E , 4A, B , 5B ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 4.
Pelagobia rubromaculata
sp. nov.
SEM. (A) dorsal view of the paratype ZMMU MSU WS14775, (B) ventral view of the paratype ZMMU MSU WS14776. Abbreviations: an—antennae, dc—dorsal cirri of parapodia, pc—pygidial cirri, ph—everted pharynx, tc—tentacular cirri, vc—ventral cirri of parapodia.

subSubSection.paragraph: Etymology. The species name is a combination of the Latin adjective ‘maculatum’ referring to the coloured speckles that these worms have dorsally, and ‘rubrum’ referring to the red colour of these speckles.

paragraph.materialsCitation:
Collected in the Nhatrang Bay of the South China Sea , depths from
0–10 m
.

subSubSection.paragraph: Distribution. South China Sea, Spratly Islands , Taiwan , Vietnam .

Remarks.
Pelagobia rubromaculata
sp. nov.
differs from
P. serrata
by the presence of eyes ( Southern 1909 ; Ushakov 1972 ; Isaychev et al . 2012). From
P. longicirrata
it differs by the shape of prostomium and by short tentacular cirri.
Pelagobia longicirrata
has pentagonal prostomium and nuchal organs forming distinct globular knobs or lappets on the lateral sides of the head, whereas
P. rubromaculata
sp. nov. has triangle prostomium and nuchal organs adherent to the cephalic lobe. Also,
P. longicirrata
has tentacular cirri reaching to 5–6 segment in contrast to tentacular cirri of
P. rubromaculata
sp. nov. reaching only the posterior edge of the third segment.
Pelagobia rubromaculata
sp. nov.
has numerous denticles on chaetal shafts, that are minute and are hard to see with a light microscope.
Pelagobia longicirrata
has smooth chaetal shafts ( Greeff 1879 ; Southern 1909 ; Isaychev 2015 ; Kolbasova 2020). Ushakov (1972) noted fine spines on chaetal shafts for some
P. longicirrata
specimens from the Pacific Ocean, but he interpreted it as morphological variation.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 5.
Pelagobia rubromaculata
sp. nov.
SEM. (A) lateral view of anterior end of the paratype ZMMU MSU WS14777, (B) posterior end of the paratype ZMMU MSU WS14776. Abbreviations: an—antennae, dc—dorsal cirrus, p—palps, pc—pygidial cirri, ph—everted pharynx, py—pygidium, tc—tentacular cirri, tp—terminal papillae, vc—ventral cirri. Arrow shows compound chaetae of tentacular segment, numbers indicate post-tentacular segments. D—dorsal side, V—ventral side.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Living
P. rubromaculata
sp. nov. differs from
P. longicirrata
by the colour pattern with red spots, that may fade after formalin fixation but are retained in those stored in alcohol. Usually, the colour pattern of living
P. longicirrata
describes as white-yellowish or white with yellow spots ( Greeff 1879 ; Ushakov 1972 ; Isaychev et al . 2012). Specimens from the Arctic are white with yellow nuchal organs and with orange spots on the lateral side of each segment and on a base of parapodial cirri (Kolbasova et al. 2020). Living
P. serrata
is also white with yellow spots on the lateral side of each segment ( Southern 1909 ).

Pelagobia rubromaculata
sp. nov.
forms a separate clade with good support ( Fig. 7 ). Surprisingly,
P. longicirrata
divides into several clades in the accordance with the geographical distribution of samples: the Arctic clade, the Central Atlantic clade and the South Atlantic clade. The specimens from the Antarctic form did not cluster into a clade due to variability of the 18S rDNA gene.

Nuclear 18S and 28S sequence data of
P. rubromaculata
sp. nov.
obtained in this study are available in Gen- Bank under accession numbers given in Table 2 . The 18S (1750 bp) p-distance between
P. rubromaculata
sp. nov.
and
P. longicirrata
from the Equatorial Atlantic is 2.8%. For
P. longicirrata
from the Antarctic it is 2.7–2.9%. For
Pelagobia sp.
from the Angola Basin the p-distance is 4.8%, for
P. longicirrata
from the Arctic it is 2.7%. The 28S (413 bp) p-distance is 4.3–5% for
P. longicirrata
from the Equatorial Atlantic, and 2.4% for
P. longicirrata
from the Arctic ( Table 3 ).
